pageContext.claim: “He [Biden] was a cheerleader for NAFTA, the worst trade deal in history.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump calls Biden a cheerleader for the North American Free Trade Agreement, but Biden actually was not initially a supporter of NAFTA, telling a local newspaper in 1993: “If I had to vote today, I would vote no.” Biden switched his support only after then President Bill Clinton negotiated side agreements related to labor an environmental issues. "We needed better protection for workers on both sides of the border, and for the environment," Biden said in a Senate floor speech. "I believe the agreements reached by the Clinton administration are a real improvement — they provide us with leverage we have never had in any other trade agreement to promote compliance by Mexico with their environmental, safety, health, and child labor laws. No, NAFTA does not transform Mexico into a mirror-image of our country, but no trade agreement can, or ever will.” The side agreements lacked enforcement mechanisms or teeth but they show Biden was not the knee jerk supporter of free trade as Trump depicts him. As we have often noted, Trump's overstates the economic impact of NAFTA. The nonpartisan Congressional Research Service in 2015 concluded the “net overall effect of NAFTA on the U.S. economy appears to have been relatively modest, primarily because trade with Canada and Mexico accounts for a small percentage of U.S. GDP.”
